article:
In the United States, 'Social Security' is the 'Old-Age, Survivors, and
Disability Insurance' ('OASDI') federal program. 42 U.S. Â§ 401,
[http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/42/401.html#a, Law.cornell.edu] retrieved
January 4, 2010. The original Social Security Act (1935) Social Security Act of 1935  and the current version
of the Act, as amended, [42 USC 7]  encompass several
social welfare and social insurance programs.

Social Security is primarily funded through dedicated payroll taxes called
Federal Insurance Contributions Act tax (FICA). Tax deposits are formally
entrusted to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund, the Federal
Disability Insurance Trust Fund, the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, or
the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund which comprise the Social
Security Trust Fund. four' [[Income inequality in
the United States|Upward redistribution of income]] is responsible for about 43%
of the projected Social Security shortfall over the next 75 years. [http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/cepr-blog/the-impact-
of-the-upward-redistribution-of-wage-income-on-social-security-solvency "The
Impact of the Upward Redistribution of Wage Income on Social Security
Solvency"]Center for Economic and Policy Research'', 12 February 2013

According to economist Martin Feldstein, the combined spending for all social
insurance programs in 2003 constituted 37% of government expenditure and 7% of
the gross domestic product. Feldstein, M. (2005).
Rethinking social insurance. [[American Economic Review]], 95(1), pp.
1â24. Social Security is currently estimated to keep roughly 40 percent of
all Americans age 65 or older out of poverty. 45. Orr, D.
(November â December, 2004). "Social Security Isn't Broken: So Why the Rush To
'Fix ' It? In C. Sturr & R. Vasudevan (Eds.), 2007, Current Economic Issues.
Boston: Economic Affairs Bureau. The Social Security Administration is
headquartered in Woodlawn, Maryland, just west of Baltimore.
